Award.AwardTitle: The adaptive variation of human skin: A comprehensive anthropological genetics examination of epidermal differentiation complex

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Skin is one of the most visible and distinguishing characteristics of humans, and understanding skin variation among humans is of central importance to the field of human biology. Indeed, there have been great advances in the last decade with regards to the genetic and developmental bases of pigmentation of the skin, explaining variation of skin color within and among human populations. However, variation in other important properties of skin, especially its barrier function, has not been well characterized. This proposal uses state-of-the-art genomic approaches to determine the extent and evolutionary relevance of skin barrier variation and address why potentially detrimental variants remain in human populations. The proposed study is at the forefront of applying novel genomic and computational technologies to anthropological questions. Specific courses and workshops are designed within the context of this project to create a major hub for training the next generation of biological anthropologists, both at the undergraduate and graduate levels. In addition, with constant public interaction, the research contributes to a better understanding of how biological evolution of the skin is independent of the cultural constructs of identity.

Recently available modern and ancient genomes allow for a comprehensive look at the evolutionary signatures in the human genome. In addition, long-read sequencing technologies now permit accurate investigation of genomic structural variants (e.g., deletions and duplications of DNA segments), which have an outsized impact on human evolution and biological variation. The proposed study uses these newly available resources to investigate the evolution of the epidermal differentiation complex, a 2Mb region on human chromosome 1, which harbors more than 50 genes with known roles in skin development and function. The genes in this complex are involved in several important functions, such as immune response, insulation from UV light, heat, moisture, and wound healing. Preliminary work indicates the presence of multiple geography-specific adaptive forces, including pathogenic pressures, shaping the genetic variation in this region, providing a glimpse of the evolution of skin barrier function in humans. The proposed project expands on this premise, to provide the most comprehensive understanding to date of the evolutionary forces acting on epidermal differentiation complex genes. In addition, the project identifies genetic variants that are of anthropological significance for human skin phenotypic variation, and are thus perfect targets for downstream functional studies. The project will also lay a methodological groundwork for future anthropological genetic studies, especially pertaining to structural variation in the human genome.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This grant investigated various aspects of genetic variation in humans pertaining to skin diversity. By doing so, the research team explored how evolutionary trends in the human lineage, such as loss of body hair, lead to specific changes that may make our skin susceptible to certain skin conditions, such as psoriasis. The research also investigated instances where interactions with Neanderthals may have contributed to genetic variation today that have implications for skin phenotypes. Last but not least, the project led to several novel methodological breakthroughs that allowed the project team to move beyond more traditional anthropological genetics work. In particular, the project helped establish genomic structural variants, which are deletions, duplications, inversions, and insertions of large genetic segments, as a major force in shaping skin phenotypes and other traits. In addition, this study identified several ancient variations that have been maintained in human populations for hundreds of thousands of years, potentially underlying biomedically relevant immune and metabolic traits. Overall, the results of this study led to more than a dozen scientific publications.


Broader Impacts: The study has provided ample opportunities to engage with the public through several venues, including the organization of STEM NY forum that aims to educate high school teachers; an invited talk on human evolution at the annual NY State Teachers’ Conference; interviews to BBC, Vice, Guardian, and other prominent media outlets; radio interviews in national and international broadcasters; an invited talk on Race and Racism at the Presidential Symposium at the American Association of Physical Anthropology (AAPA) Annual Meeting; and review papers on skin evolution and variation, anthropological genetics, and human history. In parallel, this study helped train several graduate and undergraduate students in state-of-the-art anthropological genomics approaches. The PI’s mentorship was recognized with a “Distinguished Postdoctoral Mentor Award” from the University at Buffalo (UB). The postdoctoral fellow funded by the project, Marie Saitou, has contributed to more than five manuscripts and is now a tenure-track faculty position at the Norwegian University of Life Sciences. The proposal funded a diverse group of Ph.D. students, some of whom have now graduated are now in postdoctoral positions at the University of Chicago, Weill Cornell Medical College, and the University of Paris, Sud. Within the context of this grant, the project team led efforts to organize a workshop on anthropological genomics techniques that hosted ~30 students from around the world and the inaugural GLAM-Evogen symposium with the participation of 100+ evolutionary geneticists.
